question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
After seeing that Shreya / was in trouble, / Rahul quietly stepped up to help.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-3)
option_3: Rahul quietly stepped up to help
solution:
Answer: No error

Explanation:

  • “After seeing that Shreya was in trouble” is a correct subordinate clause indicating the condition.

  • The tense and punctuation are properly used.

  • “Rahul quietly stepped up to help” is a grammatically sound main clause.

  • There is no mistake in any segment.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
He knows that / he has no other option / but to work hard.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-1)
option_3: he has no other option
solution:
Answer: No error

Explanation:
The sentence is fully correct:

  • “He knows that” introduces the subordinate clause.

  • “he has no other option” correctly expresses having no alternatives.

  • “but to work hard” idiomatically completes “no other option.”

All parts are grammatically sound and logically connected.

question:
The given sentence has an error. Select the option that contains the error in the given sentence.
We have to be cautius regarding the impact of global warming.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 25 June Shift-3 GL)
solution:
The error in the sentence is in the option:

"be cautius"

The correct spelling is "be cautious", not "cautius."

The corrected sentence should read:
"We have to be cautious regarding the impact of global warming."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) It is said / (B) that fortune / (C) favour the / (D) brave.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
The correct sentence is "It is said that fortune favors the brave," where "favors" is the correct spelling.

Generative AI is experimental. Info quality may vary. Learn more

“Fortune favors the brave” is a famous proverb that means people who face challenges with courage can achieve great success in life. The proverb suggests that people achieve success because they are brave enough to remove obstacles with courage.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
You must avoid riding in a crowded bus / or travelling in a metro / during rush hour / as both are quiet unpleasant experiences.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 13 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_2: or travelling in a metro
option_3: You must avoid riding in a crowded bus
option_4: as both are quiet unpleasant experiences
solution:
Correct Answer: as both are quiet unpleasant experiences

Solution:

  • The word "quiet" is incorrect here. It means silent or with little noise.

  • The correct word should be "quite", which means very or to a large extent.

  • So the correct sentence should be:
    "as both are quite unpleasant experiences."

Meanings:
quiet – silent or with little noise (शांत)
quite – very or extremely (बहुत)
unpleasant – not enjoyable or causing discomfort (अप्रिय)
rush hour – time when traffic is at its peak (व्यस्त समय)

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
T̲o̲ ̲m̲u̲c̲h̲ seriousness h̲a̲r̲d̲e̲n̲s̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ w̲o̲r̲l̲d̲,̲ ̲p̲i̲n̲n̲i̲n̲g̲ it down w̲i̲t̲h̲ ̲r̲u̲l̲e̲s̲.̲

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
The option that contains an error is: "to much."

Explanation: "To much" is a grammatical error. The correct form is "Too much," which indicates an excessive or undesirable amount of seriousness in this context.

The other underlined parts, "hardens the," "world, pinning," and "with rules," are correct in terms of grammar and meaning.

The corrected sentence would be: "Too much seriousness hardens the world, pinning it down with rules."

question:
The following sentence contains some errors. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The forses that genarate conditions conduciive to crime and riiots are stronger in urban communities than in rurral areas.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift_1)
option_1: The forsec that genarate conditions conduciive to crime and riots are stronger in urban communities than in rurall areas.
option_2: The forces that genarete conditions conduciive to crime and riots are stronger in urban communities than in ruraal areas.
option_3: The forces that generate conditions conducive to crime and riots are stronger in urban communities than in rural areas.
option_4: The forces that genereta conditions conducieve to crime and riotts are stronger in urban communities than in rural areas.
solution:
The correct option that rectifies the errors in the given sentence is:

The forces that generate conditions conducive to crime and riots are stronger in urban communities than in rural areas.

This option corrects the spelling errors ("forses" to "forces," "genarate" to "generate," "conduciive" to "conducive," "rurral" to "rural," and "riiots" to "riots") and provides a grammatically accurate and properly spelled sentence.Top of Form

question:
The following sentence contains some errors. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The tiger was tranquiliized in the morning and keept in a cage to avoid disturbannces by human beings.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-3)
option_1: The tiger was tranquilized in the morning and kept in a cage to avoid disturbances by human beings.
option_2: The tiger was tranquiliized in the morning and keept in a cage to avoid disturbances by human beings.
option_3: The tiger was tranquilized in the morning and kept in a cage to avoiid disturbaences by human beings.
option_4: The tiger was traanquilized in the morning and kept in a cage to avoid dissturbances by human beings.
solution:
Answer: (1) The tiger was tranquilized in the morning and kept in a cage to avoid disturbances by human beings.
Solution:
• "Tranquilized" is the correct spelling meaning to calm or sedate an animal (शांत या बेहोश करना)।
• "Kept" is the correct past tense and past participle of "keep" (रखना का भूतकाल)।
• "Disturbances" means interruptions or disruptions (परेशानियाँ या व्यवधान)।
• Other options contain spelling mistakes like "tranquiliized," "keept," "avoiid," and "dissturbances."
• Therefore, option (1) correctly rectifies all errors.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
She is quiet a generous woman / to have donated / such a large amount / for the flood affected people.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-1)
option_2: She is quiet a generous woman
option_3: for the flood affected people.
solution:
Answer: She is quiet a generous woman

Explanation:
The error lies in “quiet”, which is an adjective meaning silent. Here, the adverb “quite” (ज्यादातर) is needed as an intensifier before an adjective.

  • Use quite + adjective to mean “very” or “completely.”

  • Quiet and quite are often confused but serve different parts of speech.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Below are given alternatives to the underlined part.
Select the correct alternative.
Kanha National Park in MP is the d̲e̲n̲s̲e̲ forest in India.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.36_23-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:densest

Explanation:
The sentence is talking about one of the forests in India being the most dense, so we need the superlative form of the adjective "dense."

  • Dense → adjective (comparative: denser, superlative: densest)

  • Since we are comparing it with all other forests in India, the correct form is "densest" (सबसे घना).

Let’s look at the options:

  • denser – comparative form (used when comparing two things) → ❌

  • densest – superlative form (used when comparing more than two; the most) → ✅

  • most dense – grammatically acceptable but less common than "densest" → ❌

  • more denser – incorrect because it's a double comparative → ❌

Correct sentence:
Kanha National Park in MP is the densest forest in India.

question:
The given sentence has an error which has been underlined. The underlined word is given as options with some changes. Select the option that rectifies the error.
She v̲a̲c̲c̲i̲l̲l̲a̲t̲e̲s̲ a lot while making any decision.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-2 (26 Oct))
solution:
The correct answer is option d.

The correct spelling is Vacillates.

Vacillate:waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The speaker’s emphasiss is on the present-day problems that are being faced by ordinary men of India.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-2 (26 Oct))
option_3: by ordinary men of India
solution:
The correct answer is option d.

The correct sentence should be: “The speaker’s emphasis is”

Here is a spelling error. So, the most appropriate answer is option d.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The unseasonal rain/ caused a lot of damage/ to the crops.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
option_1: caused a lot of damage
solution:
Explanation:

Let's look at the sentence part by part:

“The unseasonal rain / caused a lot of damage / to the crops.”

  • “The unseasonal rain” – ✅ Grammatically correct; “unseasonal” is an appropriate adjective for rain that comes unexpectedly.

  • “caused a lot of damage” – ✅ Correct verb usage and object phrase.

  • “to the crops” – ✅ Correct prepositional phrase indicating what was damaged.

There is no grammatical or structural error in any part of the sentence.

✅ Therefore, the correct answer is: No error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. One of them may contain an error. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
How many / eggs were put / into the basket?

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Sentence Analysis:

“How many / eggs were put / into the basket?”

Let’s break it down:

  • "How many" – ✅ Correct interrogative phrase for countable nouns

  • "eggs were put" – ✅ Correct passive voice construction in past tense

  • "into the basket" – ✅ Correct prepositional phrase to indicate direction

✅ Meaning:

The sentence is asking: What number of eggs were placed into the basket?

Everything is grammatically and structurally correct.

✔️ Final Answer: No error ✅

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Everyone was surprised / at his indefatigable courage and determination / to achieve what he desired.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-2)
option_2: To achieve what he desired
option_3: At his indefatigable courage and determination
solution:
Answer: 1 (No error) ✅

Solution:
The sentence is:
"Everyone was surprised / at his indefatigable courage and determination / to achieve what he desired."

On re-evaluation, the sentence is grammatically and contextually correct.

  • “Indefatigable” can indeed be used with both “courage” and “determination” in literary or formal English.

  • It means persistent, tireless, and it is acceptable to describe someone’s courage as being indefatigable — especially when referring to sustained bravery over time.

✔ Therefore, no correction is needed, and the sentence reads smoothly and meaningfully.

Meaning of full sentence:
सभी लोग उसकी अथक साहस और दृढ़ संकल्प से चकित रह गए कि वह अपनी इच्छा को पूरा कर सके।

Difficult Word Meanings:
Indefatigable – never tiring or giving up; tireless (अथक, न थकने वाला)
Courage – bravery, boldness (साहस)
Determination – firmness of purpose (दृढ़ निश्चय)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Kavya finishes / her homework / before having dinner.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
he sentence is:
"Kavya finishes / her homework / before having dinner."

Let’s break it down:

  • "Kavya finishes" – This is present simple tense, appropriate if we are talking about a habitual action.

  • "her homework" – This is grammatically correct.

  • "before having dinner" – This phrase is fine and commonly used in everyday English.

  • Tense consistency – Present simple ("finishes") and the gerund ("having") work well together to express routine actions.

There is no grammatical error in the sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This artwork / are a wonderful example / of the period's vogue / for realistic style.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 3))
solution:
Answer: 3 (are a wonderful example)

Explanation:

  • Subject-verb agreement error: "This artwork" is singular, so it should be followed by "is" instead of "are."

  • Correct segment: "is a wonderful example"

Therefore, the segment with the grammatical error is "are a wonderful example."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Sam and Teena / had wondering / what to do this weekend.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.18_15-Oct_Shift-1)
option_3: what to do this weekend
solution:
Correct Answer: had wondering

Explanation:
The phrase "had wondering" is grammatically incorrect.
The correct form should be "had been wondering", which is the correct past perfect continuous tense.

Correct sentence: Sam and Teena had been wondering what to do this weekend.

So, the error is in the part "had wondering".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Maria was unhappy / because she terribly performed / in the examination / conducted last month.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.24_17-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: because she terribly performed

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "because she terribly performed."

  • The adverb "terribly" is incorrectly placed before the verb "performed."

  • Normally, adverbs of manner (like terribly) come after the verb or verb phrase in such contexts.

  • Correct phrasing would be: "because she performed terribly."

Other segments are grammatically correct.

Correct sentence:
"Maria was unhappy because she performed terribly in the examination conducted last month."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Your eldest sister / lives in / a big city, / does she?

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 13 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

⚠️ What's the error?

  • The sentence “Your eldest sister lives in a big city” is an affirmative sentence in the simple present tense.

  • Therefore, the question tag should be negative and match the tense and subject.

✅ Correct Tag Structure:

  • Main clause: Your eldest sister lives in a big city.
    ➤ Affirmative, simple present, 3rd person singular

  • So, the correct question tag is:
    ➤ doesn’t she? ✅

❌ Error:

  • The tag “does she?” is positive, which is incorrect after a positive statement.

🛠️ Part of Speech/Grammar Error:

  • Question tag formation — incorrect polarity

✔️ Corrected Sentence:

“Your eldest sister lives in a big city, doesn’t she?”

✅ Final Answer: does she ✅

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
People under eighteen / do not have / the right to vote, / don’t they?

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The correct sentence should be:
"People under eighteen do not have the right to vote, do they?"

Reason:

  • The tag question must match the main clause in tense and polarity (positive/negative).

  • Since the main sentence is negative ("do not have"), the question tag must be positive → "do they?" not "don’t they?"

Hence, Segment 4: “don’t they?” contains the grammatical error.

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
Let us work out the details of our endeavour, shouldn’t we?

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The error is in the segment "shouldn’t we".

When a sentence starts with "Let us", the appropriate question tag is "shall we?", not "shouldn’t we?".

Correct sentence:
"Let us work out the details of our endeavour, shall we?"

Option A: shouldn’t we – ❌ incorrect tag
Option B: the details of – ✔ correct
Option C: our endeavour – ✔ correct
Option D: Let us work out – ✔ correct

Answer: Option A (shouldn’t we).

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error. If there is no error, select ‘No error’.
Your mother prepares delicious food, did she?

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The sentence is: "Your mother prepares delicious food, did she?"

This contains a question tag, which must match the tense and polarity (positive/negative) of the main clause.

  • The main clause is: "Your mother prepares delicious food" → present simple tense, positive

  • So the question tag must be: "doesn't she?" (present simple, negative form)

The given tag "did she?" is incorrect — it is in the past tense and doesn't match the main clause.

Correct sentence:
"Your mother prepares delicious food, doesn't she?"

Answer: Option B (did she?).

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The 2023 report reveals that / children in India continue / to struggle on basic reading and arithmetic skills / well into their teenage years.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_1: to struggle on basic reading and arithmetic skills
option_2: well into their teenage years
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence:
    "The 2023 report reveals that / children in India continue / to struggle on basic reading and arithmetic skills / well into their teenage years."

  • Let's focus on Segment 1:
    "to struggle on basic reading and arithmetic skills"

  • The verb "struggle" is typically followed by the preposition "with", not "on", when referring to difficulties with tasks or skills.

  • Correct usage:
    "to struggle with basic reading and arithmetic skills"

Corrected sentence:

"The 2023 report reveals that children in India continue to struggle with basic reading and arithmetic skills well into their teenage years."

Segment with the error: ✅ Segment 1: "to struggle on basic reading and arithmetic skills"

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. Identify the segment that contains an error. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
People admired him, for / he lived by the same principals / that he preached.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 2)
option_4: he lived by the same principals
solution:
Correct Answer: he lived by the same principals

Explanation:
The word "principals" is incorrect in this context. The correct word should be "principles", which refers to fundamental beliefs or moral values.

  • "Principals" refers to heads of institutions or main/primary things, which does not fit the meaning of the sentence.

  • The correct sentence should be: "People admired him, for he lived by the same principles that he preached."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Solutions to the country’s interior problems are still a long way away.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 11-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct answer: - the Country’s interior

Explanation: -The term "interior" in this context is not commonly used to describe problems within a country. The correct term would be "internal", as it refers to things inside or within the country, such as internal problems or issues.

Corrected Sentence:

"Solutions to the country’s internal problems are still a long way away."

Thanks for pointing that out!

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
You have said that, / as he took money from you many times, / he owes you / five thousand rupees all together.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-1)
option_2: five thousand rupees all together
option_4: as he took money from you many times,
solution:
Correct Answer: five thousand rupees all together

Explanation:

The phrase "all together" is incorrect in this context. The correct expression should be "altogether", which means "in total" or "completely."

  • "Altogether" refers to the total sum or amount.

  • "All together" means "in a group" or "together as a unit," which doesn't fit in the sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into three segments. One of them may contain an error. Select the option that has the segment with the error. If you don’t find any error, select ‘No error’ as your answer.
Mr. Ali’s shop / is further to / the hospital.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 19-Sep Shift 2.)
solution:
The correct answer is: c

The segment with the error is "is further to".

The correct usage should be "is farther from" or "is closer to" depending on the intended meaning.

Further means to a greater degree or extent.

Farther means distance.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Dr. Sinha has / brought about a new / book on social / impact of child labour.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 17-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct answer: - "brought about a new."

Explanation: -

The correct phrase should be "brought out a new" or "published a new." The term "brought about" means to cause something to happen, which doesn't fit in this context. Here, we are talking about the introduction or publication of a new book.

So, the corrected sentence would be:

"Dr. Sinha has brought out a new book on the social impact of child labour."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
The principal gave up / the prizes to / the winners on / Republic Day.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 17-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct answer: The principal gave up

Explanation:

  • The error is in the segment "The principal gave up." The correct phrase should be "The principal gave out" (as in distributing prizes). "Gave up" means to surrender or stop trying, which does not fit the context of giving prizes.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error in the usage of the interjection.
He replied / in a dry tone, / “Ouch! I will not work / for you anymore.”

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 12-Sep Shift 3)
option_1: ''Ouch! I will not work
solution:
Correct answer: - “Ouch! I will not work”

Explanation: - The sentence contains an error in the usage of the interjection. The phrase "in a dry tone" contradicts the interjection "Ouch!".

"Ouch!" is typically used to express a sudden reaction to pain or discomfort, and it is usually said with a noticeable tone of emotion, rather than a "dry" or emotionless tone.

Therefore, the error lies in the phrase "in a dry tone," as it contradicts the expressive nature of "Ouch!" which should be said with some emotion or surprise.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Fortunately, he passed the exams / with dint of / sheer hard work and diligence.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 11 Nov Shift-1)
option_2: sheer hard work and diligence
option_4: Fortunately, he passed the exams
solution:
Answer: 1 – with dint of

Solution (Correct Option – 1: with dint of):
The error lies in the phrase "with dint of".

The correct expression is “by dint of,” which is an idiom meaning “by means of” or “because of” (के कारण / के बल पर).

Correct sentence:
"Fortunately, he passed the exams by dint of sheer hard work and diligence."

So, the error is in part "with dint of", and the correct phrase should be "by dint of."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
We have to go / under the books if / we want to pass / the board exams this year.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
option_3: the board exams this year
solution:
Answer: d) under the books if

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase “under the books if.”

  • The correct idiom is “hit the books,” which means to study hard.

  • “Under the books” is incorrect and nonsensical.

Correct sentence:
“We have to hit the books if we want to pass the board exams this year.”

Other parts are grammatically correct:

  • “We have to go” – correct

  • “we want to pass” – correct

  • “the board exams this year” – correct

Thus, option (d) contains the grammatical error because of the incorrect idiomatic phrase.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The teacher will never / give you punishment / if you will / come on time.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer:if you will

Explanation:

In conditional sentences, especially first conditionals, the structure is:

If + simple present, will + base verb

So, we should say:

✅ “If you come on time, the teacher will never give you punishment.”

Using “will” in both parts of the conditional is incorrect.

Part of speech corrected:
Modal verb – "will" is removed and replaced with simple present ("come") in the conditional clause.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The shop / usually opened / ten minutes / late.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer:usually opened

Explanation:

  • The sentence refers to a habitual action in the past, so it requires the past tense of the verb "open" used correctly in a habitual context.

  • But here, the verb “opened” is used without an auxiliary verb, making it sound like a one-time action.

Correction:

We should use “used to open” or “would open” to describe a past habitual action.

🔁 Correct sentence:
The shop usually used to open ten minutes late.
or
The shop usually opened ten minutes late (if meant as a general past statement — less formal but acceptable in some contexts).

But in this exam context, the phrase “usually opened” without clarification sounds awkward.

✅ Grammatical error is in:“usually opened”

Part of speech corrected:
Verb phrase – Should be “used to open” for past habitual action.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Mr. Suman / asked me / to pack / my luggages.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: my luggages.
Explanation: The correct plural form of "luggage" is "luggage" itself. "Luggages" is incorrect, as "luggage" is uncountable.
Other options:

  • asked me: This segment is correct.

  • to pack: This segment is also correct.

  • Mr. Suman: This segment is correct as well.

question:
Identify the error in the following sentence.
Brr, the city view from the Eiffel Tower is amazing!

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 17-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: Brr

Explanation:

The word "Brr" is typically used to express shivering or feeling cold, which does not fit the context of describing the city view from the Eiffel Tower as "amazing." It seems out of place in this sentence.

Corrected Sentence:

Wow, the city view from the Eiffel Tower is amazing!

Explanation:

  • Brr is an exclamation used to indicate shivering or coldness, which does not align with the context of admiration for a view.

  • Replacing it with Wow (expressing amazement) or Oh (indicating a general exclamation) better conveys the intended admiration for the "amazing" view. Alternatively, the sentence can start directly with "The city view..." without an exclamation if no interjection is needed.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
This is the best novel / I have read, / in a very long time.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.18_15-Oct_Shift-1)
option_2: This is the best novel
option_4: in a very long time
solution:
Correct Answer:No error

Explanation:

  • The sentence: "This is the best novel I have read in a very long time." is grammatically correct.

  • It correctly uses:

  • Superlative form: "the best novel"

  • Present perfect tense: "I have read"

  • Time expression: "in a very long time"

All segments are correctly structured and appropriately worded.

✅ Therefore, the correct answer is: No error.
